title: Dish Network-Fox outage is over after parties reach a multi-year carriage deal
text:
CLOSE Interested in cutting the cord? USA TODAY’s Jefferson Graham breaks down the best cable alternatives on Talking Tech. USA TODAY

After a 10-day service stalemate prevented thousands of subscribers from watching "Thursday Night Football," the dispute between Fox and DISH Network has officially come to a close ahead of Sunday's NFL tipoff.

Since late September, millions of Dish Network and Sling subscribers didn't have access to local Fox channels after the satellite and streaming services failed to reach an agreement with Fox Corp. The dispute came as the NFL season was entering its third week and the MLB playoffs were getting underway

Early Sunday, the opposing parties announced that a "multi-year carriage agreement" was reached and service has been restored.

“We are pleased to announce that we have reached an agreement with Dish and Sling, and they are immediately restoring their subscribers’ access to the Fox networks and television stations,” Fox said in a statement.

Dish added, "We appreciate our customers' patience as we worked to reach a long-term agreement that restores the Fox networks and local broadcast stations."

Porsche + Disney: Automaker is collaborating with movie studio to promote 'Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker'

Forbes 400: Jeff Bezos, Bill Gates and Warren Buffett remain the richest people in the US

Here we go Dish and Sling Customers all the Fox channels are back now the all NFL games are available. pic.twitter.com/GG2v0sV2tw — Peter Soregi (@PSoregi) October 6, 2019

The blackout had affected Fox’s local stations, along with FS1, FS2, BTN, Fox Soccer Plus and Fox Deportes in 17 markets across 23 states. That meant millions of viewers missed one Sunday and two Thursdays of Fox's NFL games, as well as college football and soccer matches.

In competing statements, both parties had blamed the other for the cable casualty.

Dish. (Photo: DISH Network)

Dish said in a news release that Fox was “demanding a double-digit percentage rate increase for continued carriage of its local channels” and “attempting to ‘force bundle’ its local channels and unrelated cable networks to get more money and gain negotiating leverage.”

Fox said in a separate statement: “DISH is at it again, choosing to drop leading programming as a negotiating tactic regardless of the impact on its own customers."

Follow Dalvin Brown on Twitter: @Dalvin_Brown.

description: The blackout had affected Fox’s local stations, along with FS1, FS2, BTN, Fox Soccer Plus and Fox Deportes in 17 markets across 23 states.
